stories.goal: have an interactive conversation with a named Business Analyst persona during requirements analysis
stories.benefit: my domain knowledge is captured in the requirements and no implicit assumptions go unchallenged

acceptance_criteria.given: I run `/isdlc analyze "my-feature"` and Phase 00 is complete
acceptance_criteria.then: Maya (Business Analyst) introduces herself and begins asking questions about business context

acceptance_criteria.given: Maya asks me about user needs
acceptance_criteria.then: Maya reflects my answer back ('So the primary pain point is...') before moving to the next topic
I can choose [C] to continue, [E] to elaborate, or type naturally

stories.goal: the analysis to be brief and confirmation-oriented for simple items
stories.benefit: I don't spend 20 minutes analyzing a 2-file change

acceptance_criteria.given: quick-scan classified my item as 'small' scope
acceptance_criteria.then: Maya says 'This looks straightforward. I'll keep it brief' and presents draft summaries for confirmation instead of open-ended questions

acceptance_criteria.when: I want more detail and say 'deep' or 'more detail'
acceptance_criteria.then: the agent switches to full discovery mode for the current and subsequent steps

stories.goal: resume analysis where I left off without redoing completed steps
stories.benefit: I can analyze in multiple sessions without losing progress

acceptance_criteria.then: Maya says 'Welcome back. Last time we covered business context through quality assessment. Let's pick up with feature definition.'
Alex (Solutions Architect) introduces himself and starts Phase 02 impact analysis
the context recovery takes under 5 seconds

stories.goal: a clear handoff between the Business Analyst and Solutions Architect personas
stories.benefit: I understand the shift in focus and know who is guiding me next

acceptance_criteria.then: I see a handoff message: 'Maya has finished requirements discovery. Handing off to Alex Rivera (Solutions Architect)...'
he briefly summarizes what Maya produced before diving into impact analysis

stories.goal: Alex (Solutions Architect) to present options with tradeoffs and ask about my risk appetite
stories.benefit: architectural decisions reflect my project's actual constraints rather than generic best practices

acceptance_criteria.then: he shows at least 2 options with pros/cons and asks which aligns better with my constraints
he records my choice as an ADR with rationale

stories.goal: Jordan (System Designer) to show concrete code examples and interface definitions
stories.benefit: the design documents are implementable without ambiguity

acceptance_criteria.then: it includes function signatures, data structures, and error handling patterns
they contain the concrete examples discussed, not just abstract descriptions

stories.goal: the analyze verb to fall back to standard phase agents if the roundtable agent is missing
stories.benefit: removing or renaming the roundtable agent does not break existing functionality

acceptance_criteria.then: the standard phase agents (quick-scan-agent, requirements-analyst, etc.) are used as before
the build auto-detection works identically to artifacts produced by standard agents

stories.goal: add new analysis steps by dropping a .md file into the step directory
stories.benefit: extending the analysis workflow requires no changes to the core roundtable agent

acceptance_criteria.when: the roundtable agent next runs Phase 01
acceptance_criteria.then: it discovers and executes the new step after step 08

acceptance_criteria.given: the new step file has valid frontmatter
acceptance_criteria.then: its persona, depth, and output directives are respected
